title: Tempest Of Swords And Shields
opening: Following the Alliance's defeat, the Black Eagle Strike Force prepares to invade the Kingdom, but the Kingdom's new allies--the Knights of Seiros--begin to make an advance of their own. After appearing in Ailell, the Valley of Torment, and following the border south, the Knights of Seiros openly march to recapture the monastery at Garreg Mach.

Absorbing the Alliance brings the Empire one step closer to a unified Fódlan. The Black Eagle Strike Force returns to Garreg Mach to plan its invasion of the Kingdom, unaware of the enemy lurking in the shadows.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: ...And that concludes Count Bergliez's report.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: Just as Claude said, the old Alliance has willingly fallen under Imperial rule. However, knowing him, there is no telling what manner of poison could be waiting within.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: Just as Your Majesty predicted, the old Alliance has willingly fallen under Imperial rule. However, even with Claude dead, there is no telling what manner of poison he left in his wake.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: We must be careful not to expose any weakness.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: Of course. Though it seems we can now attack the Kingdom without issue.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: True. However, you should know that Lord Arundel has entered Derdriu. It would seem he has already started collecting the Relics of the old Alliance...

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: Let him do as he pleases for now. It's not yet the time to chide him.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: Understood. As for the Kingdom... As we theorized, it is not entirely united. If we defeat the royal family of House Blaiddyd and a handful of other notable houses, it should fall under our control quite readily. Those we must target include the houses Fraldarius, Galatea, Gautier, and Charon.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: We have allies who are close to some of those lords. Perhaps that can be used to our advantage. Persuasion by tears or threats...Perhaps one would consent to act as an hostage? We must make good use of the tools given to us.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: What about House Rowe in Arianrhod, the Fortress City? Will they not side with us?

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: The head of House Fraldarius, Lord Rodrigue, has entered the city. It is possible that he has seized it.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: I see. Then it might prove too difficult to strike Fhirdiad right away.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: Either way, when preparations are complete, we can begin our deployment into the Kingdom.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: That part of the plan remains unchanged. Professor? Is something wrong?

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: No, it's nothing.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Many of those names are new to me.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: Yes, I don't imagine you have much interest in a running list of noble names. But it matters not. The nobility and the weight of it all those names will be gone once the war is over.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: This month, we must put all of our effort into preparing for battle. I'm counting on you, my teacher.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: Aaah!

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: Professor! You didn't hear anything just now, did you?

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Are you OK?

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: Of course I am! It's nothing...nothing at all.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: That was a cute shriek.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: Cute?! Huh! Well, be that as it may, it is not your concern. It was nothing.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Are you sure about that?

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: I told you it was nothing and I meant it.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Really, very cute...

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: You seem to be trying your hardest to infuriate me. Don't you dare say that again!

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: Cute?! Huh! Well, be that as it may, it is not your concern. It was nothing.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: It's just... Well, there was a rat. I don't enjoy the company of rats. I believe I've told you about this before...about when I was held captive beneath the palace. There were a lot of rats there. To this day, I just...

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: What's that?

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: What?! Oh! Professor! Leave here at once! I recall now that Hubert needs to speak with me. I must change my clothes. Now. Whatever you do, don't look this way.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: I already saw it...

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: Aah! Then forget what you saw! That's an order!

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: If the Alliance falls, then the Kingdom will... There's no time to waste. If we hesitate, we risk losing the initiative. I do think we should let the troops rest, though... We must maintain morale, Professor. And let's make sure this matter stays between us. If it gets out, I'll struggle to forgive even you.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: What matter?

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Hmm... It seems you don't comprehend the consequences of angering the emperor.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Understood.

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Thank you.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: Claude von Riegan. What an interesting character. Underneath that compassionate exterior, he was always cold and calculating. Ordinary fools run headlong into combat, without even considering the possibility of defeat. But to consider one's chances, and to prepare for plans to go awry--that takes real intelligence. I have to say, I am impressed beyond words.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: The majority is with us. This conflict will end soon. I am so moved by the Alliance nobles' decision. That is true nobility! Acting in accordance with the people's needs and wishes. As war drags on, those living near the front lines inevitably get the worst of it. We will not see such a peaceful resolution in Faerghus, I am afraid, as it is ruled by the royal family, not a council of nobles.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: I've been exploring the Holy Mausoleum. It's quite interesting in there. There is a mechanism I believe would allow us passage into the Holy Tomb, but I'm unclear on how to activate it. My research hasn't turned up much. It may come down to asking the archbishop for details.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Your research will find something.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's a puzzler.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: Indeed. We'll see if it's worth the trouble.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Did you meet my father in Derdriu? I guess he'll be responsible for controlling the Riegan territory and maintaining popular support. Not really sure what all that means though...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You should study more.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: You're probably right. I'll do my best!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It doesn't matter.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Are you sure? I figured you'd say something about me having to study more. Oh, I get it. This is a test! I'm definitely gonna have to brush up.

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: War isn't kind to you if you're a recluse. By the time you realize what's going on, you're already under attack. And if you're off by yourself, you can get killed with no one ever even finding out.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Sounds like you're learning.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Isn't that a little pessimistic?

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: Got me out of my room, at least! That's good, right?

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: The Leicester Alliance is no more. Three hundred years of history...gone and done. They write operas about events like this, you know. I'm sure they'll have a talent and beautiful songstress playing you. Probably for Edie as well. I wonder if there'll be romantic tension between your two characters, even if it's not historically accurate?

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: The Leicester Alliance is no more. Three hundred years of history...gone and done. They write operas about events like this, you know. I'm sure you'll be played by the most handsome actor of the time. Hearts will pound as he takes the stage. A diva will play Edie! You'll fall madly in love, even if it isn't historically accurate.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: The Kingdom always is cold. I have hatred for the cold. Brigid is not cold. We have no Cold Spirit. Does the goddess of Fódlan give protection from the cold? I am wishing I knew how to ask her...

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Hmph. My father is holding Arianrhod secure. Our next battle will be there, against him, or in Fhirdiad, which the king is protecting.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Can you fight them?

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Ha! Don't underestimate me. I've been preparing for this for a long time.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'm counting on you.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Hah. You just worry about yourself.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: Derdriu's fallen. The Alliance nobles have surrendered to the Empire. We made it through with as few losses as possible. Not bad, all things considered... But I doubt it'll be so easy to deal with Faerghus.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: First Leicester and next Faerghus? Ah, that'll be really tough. Look, Professor... Fighting Faerghus? Isn't there some way we can come to an understanding?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Maybe there is.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Yeah, but Edelgard and her idiot sidekick haven't shown much desire to compromise, have they?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: No.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Harsh...but true. I don't see how we can avoid what's coming.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Truthfully, I hate the idea of planning to kill people I used to be so close with. I guess everybody feels that way though.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Oh, Claude. I'm so relieved that he managed to make it out alive. You'll be fighting the Kingdom next, right? Then the church? Isn't there some way we can do this without fighting Dimitri and Lady Rhea? I suppose not...

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Oh, Claude. It's too late now, but it's such a shame... You'll be fighting the Kingdom next, right? Then the church? I guess Edelgard won't hesitate to cut Dimitri and Lady Rhea down...

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: We may be witnessing a key moment in history. Hundreds of years from now, your name and Edelgard's will be written in the history books, Professor!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Perhaps.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's a little embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: What, how? I think it's just amazing!

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: I wonder who will decide whether we did the right thing or not... Well, it won't be us, anyway. Probably the people of a future era.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: While the battle with the Alliance is over, we still need to stay vigilant. Both the church and the Kingdom are not to be taken lightly. I have the feeling we'll draw their attention soon. Weapon prep and training are of the utmost importance now more than ever.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: It seems all that praise of Claude's ingenuity was largely unfounded. A truly clever man would have realized defeat was inevitable and surrendered. Or, failing that, he could have rallied the Alliance nobles to secure a real fighting chance.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: I'm no noble, so it won't make much difference to me... But it hasn't really hit me yet that the Alliance is finished.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: To think, I saw the end of the Leicester Alliance with my own eyes. I witnessed a turning point in the history of my homeland. I'm not sure how to express my feelings right now.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Why not write about it?

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: No, I don't have a gift for words. But perhaps I'll tell my children someday, if I have any.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Why not paint a picture?

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: That's right, I'll paint it! The Fall of Derdriu.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: So that posterity can remember our triumph.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: The battle ended without House Ordelia getting involved. Although...I've no desire to continue on with my family, so from here on out, it's up to Edelgard. I have Claude to thank. Ultimately, this ended without the Alliance being entirely consumed by war. It's all thanks to Claude.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: I have Claude to thank. Before the battle, he considered my precarious position and told me it wouldn't matter if we fell to the Empire. So when you invited me, I accepted without hesitation. Ultimately, this ended without the Alliance being entirely consumed by war. It's all thanks to Claude.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I wonder... Was there really no way to end it without fighting Claude?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It couldn't be helped.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: You're probably right...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's better this way.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I hope you're right...

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I suppose the only thing I can do for him now is pray...

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: That he may live the rest of his life in happiness.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: That he may rest in peace.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: The worst part about going to battle is knowing you might have a friend fighting for the other side. You were a mercenary, Professor. Were you always prepared for that?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Absolutely.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Guess I need to learn. Won't make a very good mercenary otherwise, will I?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I still hesitate.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: That's reassuring. I don't think I'll ever get used to it.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Fighting old friends--there's nothing worse. My hands shake just thinking about it.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: I'm glad Claude didn't die. Does that make me soft?

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: I didn't want Claude to die. Does that make me soft?

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: I've lived at Garreg Mach Monastery for a few decades now. Still, the other day I got myself all turned around! There are so many secret rooms and hidden passages. Maybe I'll take the time to properly search the place. Care to join me? I expect it'd take a whole day.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: You're too soft. I'm talking about Claude. Our emperor mercilessly cuts down all those who stand in her way... But perhaps she is more tolerant of those who know their place.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Our emperor mercilessly cuts down all those who stand in her way... Even the Master Tactician.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: It seems Claude has disappeared...

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Claude...lost in battle. My goodness.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Do you suppose this means the end of House Riegan? While the Crest of von Riegan is not terribly rare... The long linage of the von Riegan family will be broken.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's just another consequence of war.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We should mourn his death.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Agreed. The poor boy...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Does this pose an obstacle to your research?

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: No... At the very least, I think not. There are other, lesser Crests to research. Yet I am a human first and a scholar second. For now, I grieve the fallen and pray for those still living.

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: You know as well as I do, the day's coming that we'll have to fight the archbishop and her knights. We've got some strong fighters here, sure. But even with all our training, I don't know if we can win. I just don't see how any of us can compete with the archbishop, say, turning into a monster.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: If we must fight, we will.

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: Yeah? What if that fight's to the death--yours and mine in particular?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Sometimes it can be better to retreat.

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: That's exactly what I was saying. I've always appreciated how you listen to me.

conversation.speaker: Jeritza
conversation.line: Neither the emperor nor the Empire have my allegiance. It is all simply part of the agreement. There is no other reason for me to be here.

conversation.speaker: Anna
conversation.line: The Alliance is just...gone. It's hard to believe. The merchants of Derdriu all have nerves of steel. I'm sure they'll be up and running again in no time.

conversation.speaker: Randolph
conversation.line: Finally, the Kingdom... After that, we'll battle the church. I volunteered for monastery guard duty. It was more for my family than anything. But now, from the bottom of my heart, I want to see Her Majesty ruling this land. Even if it costs me my life, I will protect Garreg Mach!

conversation.speaker: Fleche
conversation.line: I just wanted to help out my brother, Randolph, so I aspired to be a soldier. My brother puts his life on the line to fight, so I'll put everything I have into it too. Eventually the enemy will attack, and when they do, we'll defend this place to the bitter end!

conversation.speaker: Ladislava
conversation.line: Your next opponents will be the Kingdom's army and the Knights of Seiros. Both fearsome foes. Put the mobility of my troops to good use, and let us protect the Kngdom's western battle front. When this month has ended, I'll depart. I pray that you have good luck in battle.

conversation.speaker: Gatekeeper
conversation.line: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! You may already know this, but the Kingdom and the Alliance were once a single entity. The leaders of the Alliance, House Riegan, are actually a branch of the Blaiddyd royal family. In a way, it's just a battle of the part of Blaiddyd family tree that rose in rebellion against the Empire...

intro.speaker: Imperial Soldier
intro.line: Raid from the north! Their flag bears the symbol of the Knights of Seiros! One of our troops has already intercepted them! Your Majesty, please give us your orders!

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: From the north? Interesting... Could it be they journeyed through Ailell, the Valley of Torment? Is the archbishop among the enemy ranks? If so, focus our attacks on her first.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: Our enemy knows Garreg Mach from inside and out. They can come and go as they please. It would have been best if we had detected them sooner, but that can't be helped. Professor. We must hurry and intercept them ourselves. I'll leave the preparations to you.

intro.speaker: Hubert
intro.line: Heh. The battle looks to be rather cumbersome. We are still guarding all of Garreg Mach, but there are undoubtedly numerous secret passages and magic traps... There is still much about this place that we do not know. It is quite possible that they will attack from a location we cannot anticipate.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: I must head out first to give my orders. I'll meet up with you soon. Call for General Randolph and General Ladislava! Hurry!

intro.speaker: Seteth
intro.line: It feels like only yesterday we called this place our home... We must show these fools the error of their ways. They shall pay for the sin of invading Garreg Mach...

intro.speaker: Flayn
intro.line: Oh, but the professor is fighting alongside our foe! The same one who saved my life...

intro.speaker: Seteth
intro.line: That is true... Though I find forgiveness difficult, we do owe that wayward soul a debt. However, the fact remains that because of the professor, Rhea has long been tormented. To think that the vessel of the goddess, entrusted with the Sword of the Creator, could go on to... Ah, it angers me to even think of it! All that has happened has changed Rhea. I imagine it has changed the professor as well. Even if we prevail, I doubt the church can ever fully return to the way it once was...

intro.speaker: Seteth
intro.line: Dear Flayn. I only brought you with me because you were so insistent. Still, no matter what happens, you must not go near the front lines. If something were to happen to you, it would utterly destroy me. You are my reason for breathing. Do you understand?

intro.speaker: Flayn
intro.line: I...I understand. If something were to happen to you, it would break my heart. I could not go on either. I cannot help but wonder...if there is a way to end this without fighting the professor...

battle.speaker: Shamir
battle.line: Our surprise attack on Garreg Mach was a success. Now we just need to break through past this point.

battle.speaker: Knight Of Seiros
battle.line: We were successful sneaking up on Garreg Mach. All that's left is to break through past this point.

battle.speaker: Alois
battle.line: Lady Rhea and Catherine are holding back most of the Empire's army. Thereby leaving us, the expeditionary force, free to recapture the monastery!

battle.speaker: Knight Of Seiros
battle.line: The archbishop and Catherine are handling the bulk of the Imperial army. That gives us the chance to infiltrate the monastery!

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: Our enemies have followed us even here. How unfortunate.

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: Your Majesty, the enemy's movement is suspicious. They may have some tactic in mind.

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: If so, then let's face them without delay. Form defensive lines and hold them to the death! Strike down all who approach!

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: Their troop composition is also strange. I would bet that they are concealing additional soldiers.

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: The enemy is transporting large quantities of flammable material into the woods. They clearly intend to attack us with fire. We should do all we can to prevent it.

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: Troops waiting in the woods to ambush? We must avoid any suspicious areas as we advance.

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: Come at me, so that I may put you out of your misery! (Flayn and several Church Soldiers appear on the right side of the map.

battle.speaker: Flayn
battle.line: The time is now! As long as we stand here, you shall not pass!

battle.speaker: Alois
battle.line: Now! Light it up! Like the goddess's fiery wrath, these flames will engulf our enemies.

battle.speaker: Shamir
battle.line: Great. A path has opened for us.

battle.speaker: Knight Of Seiros
battle.line: All right, a second route is open! Well done on this one too!

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: If they break through here, the monastery will be — ...If that happens, all will be lost.

boss.speaker: Seteth
boss.line: Trespassing on holy ground is a grave sin indeed. You must atone for it with your life!

boss.speaker: Seteth
boss.line: I'm sorry, Rhea... For Flayn's sake, I must take my leave to retreat...

boss.speaker: Seteth
boss.line: I'm sorry, Flayn... I couldn't protect you...

boss.speaker: Seteth
boss.line: It saddens me to face you on the field of battle, after all you've done for Flayn. I cannot approve of your actions. But I also cannot follow Rhea on her current course. It may not change anything, but allow me to make a promise to you. If Flayn and I survive this battle, we will withdraw from the world and leave you to do as you please.

end.speaker: Randolph
end.line: Edelgard... Your Majesty... I am so sorry...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Silence. We must tend to your wounds.

end.speaker: Randolph
end.line: It will do no good. I can't be saved... You must know that. Ladislava has also passed... The enemy has withdrawn... You are safe now...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Understood. Good work. Another loss on my watch... As more blood wets my feet, they grow heavier with each step. Remorse, resentment, despair... I have dispensed with all such things to come this far.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: And we must keep moving forward...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Hubert. Tell me the status of the enemy.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: The battle has ended in a draw with severe injuries on both sides. Some known commanders have been slain.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: The most worthy of mention among the dead was the second in command to Rhea herself, Seteth.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: With the death of Alois, the Knights of Seiros have taken a huge blow as well.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Garreg Mach has not taken much damage, and so it would not be out of line to claim it as a victory for us.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Yes... We'll call that a victory. Although, I'm sure they will say the same.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Yes, Your Majesty.

end.speaker: Bernadetta
end.line: Ugh, what a terrible opponent that was! Why is the church always like this?! How am I supposed to train for that?! It was way too scary!

end.speaker: Linhardt
end.line: When I saw the enemy enter Garreg Mach, I prepared myself mentally for death. I thought it would be a fine time to die, but I suppose it wasn't quite the time after all...

end.speaker: Petra
end.line: Our luck was good to have grabbed victory. The church has great strength. We must not have grief, but must keep fighting. Can we be fighting now?

end.speaker: Ferdinand
end.line: This was certainly a momentous victory. We lost a lot, but we also gained a lot. Certain lords in the Kingdom have examined the situation again and decided to join our cause. Changing their fealty based on just one battle... They are all a disgrace to the nobility!

end.speaker: Dorothea
end.line: Today, our enemy held many faces I knew well... If we must fight to the death with that kind of opponent, what will become of this world?

end.speaker: Caspar
end.line: There's no stopping me! I'm ready go strike the Kingdom here and now! Everyone must see that we can easily unite Fódlan! Don't you think?

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Excellent job, everyone. The battle is over now.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Professor, the battle is over now.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: While we have sustained heavy losses, our foe has suffered far more.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Although not exactly as planned, a win is a win. It may be safe to say that there will be no more obstacles on our way to the next battle.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: We will break through the Tailtean Plains and then set course for Fhirdiad, the Kingdom Capital. The final chapter of our fight with the Kingdom and the church is close at hand.
